lom:description.lom:string: "This study examines the construction of choice for young women with regard to selection of math and science coursework at the high-school level. In contrast to most studies of gender and math, this study focuses on the decision making process of girls, rather than on the causes of differential math and science performance. Little qualitative work has been done on the choices of young women of color with regard to math and science. It is hypothesized that the process of the formation of the scientific pipeline varies by race/ethnicity and gender with regard to the social construction of identity. Further, organizational processes connecting young women to extra-curricular resources frequently reproduce larger inequalities in adult society. The site selection of extra-curricular programs organized around training young people to be interested in math and science in Boston are an appropriate subject for this study. Boston is a diverse metropolitan area with a history of tense race relations but an active NGO presence and strong philanthropic and educational resources. The ethnography to date includes observations of both female and male students as well as interviews with teachers. The site for data gathering comprises numerous local non-profits which have expressed an interest in the study."

lom:keyword.lom:string: math, science, technology, girl, girls, participation, attract, recruitment, engage, retain, women, motivation

lom:title.lom:string: Adding value perceptions of Boston educators regarding girls participation in math, science and technology
